Posts.Content: nred2002 wrote: Just wondering if anyone else has had a finding of "hypertrophic pulmonary arthropathy" on their bone scan?  This showed up on mine (I do plan to ask onc about it), and everything I've googled says it relates to joint and bone pain (which I don't have) and is sometimes an effect of lung cancer (which I also don't have). Any thoughts?  Dx 11/27/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 1/7/2011 Lumpectomy: Left Radiation Therapy 2/20/2011 Breast Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2011 Arimidex (anastrozole) Dx 12/3/2014, IDC, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 1/15/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 09:11AM nred2002 wrote: I have this too.  In fact, I also have a blue area that looks like a bruise.  My surgeon said it is a reaction to the blue dye that is injected after the radioactive stuff.  She said it can take up to two months to dissipate.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2015 06:36PM nred2002 wrote: I got the vaccine a week ago. I was more than a month out from the last dose of eribulin and my blood levels were fine. Today I had more blood tests and was puzzled that my WBC had dropped from 5.1 to 3.4. Then I remembered the shingles shot---pretty sure this did it. Also a bit more tired than usual. Another few weeks until I go on either Palbo or an equivalent study drug so will give my system time to process. Both Oncs I consulted said fine and go for it.
Posts.Title: Question about the shingles vaccine dlb823 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2015 03:20AM nred2002 wrote: Sandpointer,  Yes, that is the trial I am in. I was randomized to the eribulin arm. Without the trial the onc wanted to put me on Taxol, so this gave us another option.l It is going well for me so far, and hope it continues. My WBC count took a hit the second and third doses, but it is back up to normal today (Dose 2 of Cycle 2). I am losing some hair (in strands, not chunks) and they are working on adjusting premeds for constipation, but otherwise doing fine so far.  Nancy
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2015 12:55AM nred2002 wrote: Sandpointer,  That is exactly the point at which my hair started to thin as well. this week, it is still thinning a bit, but pace/number of strands seems to have lessened. The onc and nurse changed the pre meds and I didn't have constipation. No fatigue, though I sleep a bit more for a couple of days after the treatment. Hope this continues for both me and your mom! And that it works!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2015 05:10PM nred2002 wrote: Syrmom and livebyfaith, I had some constipation at the beginning. Both the doctor and infusion nurse thought the culprit more likely to be the premeds than the eribulin itself. They adjusted these (I also get the lowest possible dose of decadron) and by also being proactive with Colace and Smooth Move tea (I start these the day before the infusion and take day of and after), things are going much better. My first infusion nurse also gave me her "three w's" --water, walking and washing--and these have also helped. I have had only minimal side effects so far (begin Cycle 4 this Thursday). My blood counts took a hit the first couple of doses, but seem to have bounced back--on the low end of normal, but still normal. I sleep a bit more the two days after the infusion, but am not fatigued during the day. In fact this am I ran 7 miles. My hair thinned quite a bit the first two cycles, but this has also slowed (still losing strands of hair, though). Really hoping for a long run with this drug. Nancy
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2015 12:30AM nred2002 wrote: I am 63 (almost 64) and glad to find this thread. Was first diagnosed at age 59 and it came back in December to the axilla, with mets to bones and scattered lymph nodes. Currently on a clinical trial randomized to Eribulin which I've been tolerating well, and the one lymph node I can feel (in axilla) seems to be shrinking. I will have a scan in April to determine if it's knocking the other mets back as well.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2015 02:22AM nred2002 wrote: Syrmom,  Wishing you luck on the scan. For constipation, ask them to dial back any premeds that are anti-nausea. I did this and it helped a lot. Also on glutamine, so far no issues with neuropathy. Nancy

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 07:49PM nred2002 wrote: That's great news! I have my first scan after 4 cycles of Halaven (I start Cycle 4 on Thursday) on April 9. The lymph node under my arm is definitely smaller so also hoping for good news.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2015 11:45PM nred2002 wrote: Well, I'm off Halaven after 8 cycles. Yesterday's scan continued to show progression in the bones (worse than in April, and now showing up on the CT scan as well), so it wasn't tumor flare--appears that it simply never worked on my bones. Lymph nodes shrunk a little more or remained stable, but doc thought the slowing of shrinkage was a sign that the drug is "petering out" even with those. I'll get the results of the Foundation One study done at Ohio State (which isn't released until you have progression) and compare with the Dartmouth doctors' recommendation of Ibrance/Femara as the next line. Best of luck to all of you on this drug, it was an easy one for me, and I'm sorry it didn't work longer/better.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 08:30PM nred2002 wrote: You are doing exactly the right thing by having another mammogram  quickly.  I don't want to scare you, but this is how mine presented--I also felt no lump but had an indentation that was not visible unless I tensed my chest muscles.  The lump showed up on the mammogram and ultrasound.  I had surgery yesterday and feel well enough to be on line.... Debbie is right--the waiting is the worst part. But take comfort that you are doing the right thing.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 10:58AM nred2002 wrote: She is now at peace, which is a blessing.   I have read both her books and she mentioned in one of them, quite innocently and in passing, that John had lost about 5 wedding rings since they were married--she went out and bought him several replacements.  That just kind of jumped out at me as an obvious sign that his "character defect"  is probably of quite long standing. I too am grateful for a wonderfully supportive husband.

Posts.Title: Palbociclib (Ibrance): Who would get this? RosesToeses Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2015 07:42PM nred2002 wrote: I just went through this as well. Bone scan was pulled ahead and scared me to death--looked like new mets and progression. But the doc said he thought this could as easily be tumor flare--and from the results of the CT scan, it was--lymph nodes shrunk by 30-40% and no new mets. Yay! I was worried that I would be kicked out of the trial I'm in, where I'm getting eribulin which has been a really easy drug for me. Because of the way the bone scan report was written up, they had to call the national team running the trial to keep me in, but that team agreed. So I'm good for another 12 weeks at least, and I hope longer!
